data.title: "Open Recent" fails to open projects after closing all previously open Atom windows
data.body:
### Prerequisites

* [x] Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
* [x] Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
* [x] Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
* [x] Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
* [n/a] Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

After closing a number of Atom windows (I tested between 1 and 4, all different projects), selecting a project from `File -> Open Recent` results in the project not being opened.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Open any number of Atom windows
2. Close all opened windows.
3. Select a project from `File -> Open Recent`

**Expected behavior:** 
The selected project would open.

**Actual behavior:** 
The project doesn't open.

**Reproduces how often:**
Since I noticed the behavior this morning, I'm able to reproduce it 100% of the time.

### Versions

```
MacOS Sierra (10.12.6)

Atom    : 1.18.0
Electron: 1.3.15
Chrome  : 52.0.2743.82
Node    : 6.5.0

apm  1.18.1
npm  3.10.10
node 6.9.5 x64
python 2.7.10
git 2.11.0
```
### Additional Information
I'm not seeing this behavior when I have at least one project window open.

data.title: Open Project and blank page
data.body:
OS : arch : gnome
atom version : 1.18.0-2

I want atom to open every time after close with just a folder pane and bank untitled page 


#### open empty editor on start : ticked
#### restore previous windows on start : set to no


yet every time it restarts the tree folder pane is still there and so are the pages that were previously opened

I want to be able to always open atom with project folders and a blank page ready to start , but it keeps restoring the pages and tabs that were previously opened

data.title: Should not use bind for map's callback in pane.coffee.
data.body:
`Array.prototype.map` call callback with `callback(item, index, this)`.
So using `bind` is not appropriate for the function which take 2nd arg.

cc @maxbrunsfeld 

### Requirements

* Filling out the template is required. Any pull request that does not include enough information to be reviewed in a timely manner may be closed at the maintainers' discretion.
* All new code requires tests to ensure against regressions

### Description of the Change

I found this via code-reading. Not sure there is already reported issue.
Calling `pane.destroyItems()` don't `@promptToSaveItem` for items with index greater than 0.
Since map pass index, index goes to `force` arg of `destroyItems`. `force` become true unless index `0`.

<!--

We must be able to understand the design of your change from this description. If we can't get a good idea of what the code will be doing from the description here, the pull request may be closed at the maintainers' discretion. Keep in mind that the maintainer reviewing this PR may not be familiar with or have worked with the code here recently, so please walk us through the concepts.

-->

### Alternate Designs

No

<!-- Explain what other alternates were considered and why the proposed version was selected -->

### Why Should This Be In Core?

Bug
<!-- Explain why this functionality should be in atom/atom as opposed to a package -->

### Benefits

Bug free.
<!-- What benefits will be realized by the code change? -->

### Possible Drawbacks

No.
<!-- What are the possible side-effects or negative impacts of the code change? -->

### Applicable Issues

<!-- Enter any applicable Issues here -->

data.title: Independent Atom instances (per $ATOM_HOME)
data.body:
**What problems does this solve?** Let's assume I have two `$ATOM_HOME` directories `A/` and `B/`, with different packages, themes etc. Currently, if I start Atom in the following way

```bash
$ ATOM_HOME=A/ atom
$ ATOM_HOME=B/ atom
```
the second one opens up a new Atom window, but uses packages etc. from `A/`, which feels counter-intuitive. Instead I propose that instances would be per `$ATOM_HOME`. On Linux this can be achieved by having sockets be per-`$ATOM_HOME` it seems.

This would be helpful for IDEs (e.g. [Juno](http://junolab.org/)) which load a lot of IDE-specific features and UI components. With this PR you could simply have a `juno` "executable" that wraps around an existing Atom installation, but does not interfere with normal Atom usage:

```sh
#!/bin/sh
export ATOM_HOME=$HOME/.juno
exec atom $@
```

**How does it solve it?** This PR puts the socket into `$ATOM_HOME`, instead of `os.tmpdir()`.

I've been running `1.20.0-dev` with this change for a week or so now and it has been working fine so far. But I'm not sure whether this particular PR is the best solution.

Also, it is Linux-specifc (and macOS?). I can't test this on macOS, nor provide a solution for Windows. If someone could provide a more complete solution I'd be happy if this PR would be superseded.

**Drawbacks/alternatives.** I don't see this affecting normal Atom usage in any way.

In case sockets have to be under `os.tmpdir()` (due to potential filesystem permission issues or something like that?), then an alternative would be to have a `abspath(process.env.ATOM_HOME)`-dependent piece in the socket name, where `abspath` would resolve any relative paths etc.

data.title: Replace font stack with Chromium 56's "system-ui" generic font family
data.body:
### Description of the Change

Atom currently [does not use the system font](https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/8656), but instead hardcodes a bunch of fonts in a "font stack" (priority list), hoping that the actual system font is present in that list and in the right position.

This doesn't always work and gives particularly poor results on Linux, where changing the system font is easy and Atom stands out as the one application that doesn't respect the change. The reason this long-standing issue is still open is that until recently this wasn't possible to fix from CSS (except on macOS with the `BlinkMacSystemFont` placeholder family) and would have required platform-specific code that resolves the correct family.

Enter Chromium 56, shipping with Atom 1.19! It introduces the [`system-ui` generic font family](https://www.chromestatus.com/feature/5640395337760768) that "allows authors to style contents so it fits within the system UI". It works on all platforms! 🎉 🎆 🍾 

Closes #8656. The same change should probably be made also in Atom's default UI themes.

### Alternate Designs

The alternatives are keeping the font stack, or resolving the system font family programmatically. Both are clearly worse.

### Why Should This Be In Core?

Because the font family is defined in core.

### Benefits

Atom looks a tiny bit more like a native application.

### Possible Drawbacks

Can't think of any.

### Applicable Issues

#8656

===





### Description

https://i.stack.imgur.com/Cdb4G.jpg

MacOS Serria: 10.12.2 (16C67)


### Additional Information

I find as long as I open the Atom, the CPU usage will get to 100%

data.title: Atom crashes when copying contents from one editor tab to another. MacOS Sierra
data.body: ### Prerequisites * [X] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following: * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/ * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages ### Description I received the below message **after** pasting all the text of a 33.8MB file into a new untitled file. > The editor has crashed. Please report the issue to https://github.com/atom/atom ### Steps to Reproduce 1. Open a large file (e.g. [The file causing Atom to crash - Hosted On Google Drive](https://drive.google.com/open?id=0B2YHKXTPh6ezTU5hQkJ4TzN6cXM)) 2. Press (Cmd + A) then press (Cmd + C) to put the contents of the file on your clipboard 3. Press (Cmd + N) to open a new untitled document. 4. Press (Cmd + V) to paste your clipboard contents into the new untitled document. **Expected behavior:** Editor does not crash **Actual behavior:** after about 10 seconds the editor will paste the contents into the new untitled document. However, the user interface will remain frozen even after the editor is filled with the contents from your clipboard. After another 5 seconds the editor crashes. Opening Atom in safe mode from the terminal yields the below results ``` $ /Application/Atom\ Beta.app/Contents/MacOS/Atom\ Beta --safe <--- Last few GCs ---> [21851:0x7f8c91847a00] 83407 ms: Mark-sweep 1405.7 (1465.1) -> 1405.6 (1434.1) MB, 1254.6 / 6.0 ms (+ 0.0 ms in 0 steps since start of marking, biggest step 0.0 ms, walltime since start of marking 1255 ms) last resort [21851:0x7f8c91847a00] 84607 ms: Mark-sweep 1405.6 (1434.1) -> 1405.6 (1434.1) MB, 1199.2 / 2.3 ms last resort <--- JS stacktrace ---> ==== JS stack trace ========================================= Security context: 0x1662a60519c1 2: new Symbol [:~206370] [pc=0x16f63ecca07](this=0x29340d1c9239 ,text=0x29340d1c8c21 ,scopes=0x29340d1c8a31 ) 4: recomputeSymbolsForEditorInBufferRange [:~206487] [pc=0x16f63fa77f2](this=0x9505fd55d81 ,editor=0x38f711946929 ... ``` **Reproduces how often:** 100% ### Versions ``` $ /Application/Atom\ Beta.app/Contents/MacOS/Atom\ Beta --version Atom : 1.19.0-beta4 Electron: 1.6.9 Chrome : 56.0.2924.87 Node : 7.4.0 ``` Specs: ``` MacBookPro13,2 (A1706) macOS Sierra: Version 10.12.5 ``` ### Additional Information I am running the 64-bit build of atom. Interestingly the amount of RAM that was in use by Atom when I pasted the contents of the first editor into the untitled document jumped. **These tests were done on a file 33.8MB in size.** With no document loaded Atom sat at around ~330MB With the document loaded Atom sat between 520MB - 700MB When I copied the document to a new untitled document, Atom jumped to ~2.0GB - 2.14GB then crashed. [Atom Beta Helper_2017-07-27-211501_Ethans-MacBook-Pro.crash.txt](https://github.com/atom/atom/files/1195136/Atom.Beta.Helper_2017-07-27-211501_Ethans-MacBook-Pro.crash.txt)

data.title: Wrong cursor behavior when moving from tree view to editor
data.body:
Running Atom 1.18.0 on OS X 10.10.5

**Expected behavior:** the cursor should always be a text cursor when hovering over code in the editor.
**Actual behavior:** clicking on the tree view then clicking on code switches the cursor to default pointer.

A gif to illustrate:

![cursor](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/7478535/28492601-d5ea37cc-6f06-11e7-889b-9fa88c9e5fa3.gif)

Related issues: #8566 #9489 #12314

data.title: Can't switch tabs with keyboard when tree view is focused
data.body:
Running Atom 1.18.0 on OS X 10.10.5

Using keyboard shortcuts <kbd>⌘</kbd>+<kbd>⌥</kbd>+<kbd>←</kbd> and <kbd>⌘</kbd>+<kbd>⌥</kbd>+<kbd>→</kbd> doesn't switch tabs when the tree view is focused.

I have keyboard shortcuts assigned to specific gestures on the mac trackpad and they should work everywhere in the app, regardless of where the cursor is. This is also inconsistent behavior as closing and reopening tabs with <kbd>⌘</kbd>+<kbd>W</kbd> and <kbd>⌘</kbd>+<kbd>⇧</kbd>+<kbd>T</kbd> works as intended.

### Steps to Reproduce

With 2 file tabs open and the tree view visible:

1. Click to focus the tree view.
2. Use <kbd>⌘</kbd>+<kbd>⌥</kbd>+<kbd>←</kbd> to switch to previous tab.

**Expected behavior:** To switch to previous tab.

**Actual behavior:** Tab switching doesn't work with that key combo.

data.title: Can't open the specified path on startup if --disable-gpu is appended
data.body:
### Prerequisites

* [x] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

Atom cannot open the specified path on startup if `--disable-gpu` is appended to the command.  Adding `--safe` to the command doesn't change anything.

![screenshot from 2017-07-22 09-35-06](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/515636/28486777-1262f068-6ec1-11e7-8067-552b940a3b5d.png)

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Run `atom --disable-gpu .` in a directory.

**Expected behavior:** Atom opens the specified directory on startup.

**Actual behavior:** Atom opens a blank editor on startup.

**Reproduces how often:** everytime

### Versions

Atom    : 1.18.0
Electron: 1.3.15
Chrome  : 52.0.2743.82
Node    : 6.5.0

### Additional Information

`--disable-gpu` is necessary as a workaround for #14776.

data.title: Use underscore deepClone instead of self implementation
data.body:
Fixes: https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/13980

### Requirements

* Filling out the template is required. Any pull request that does not include enough information to be reviewed in a timely manner may be closed at the maintainers' discretion.
* All new code requires tests to ensure against regressions

### Description of the Change
Use `_.deepClone` instead of self implementation

data.title: Keyboard Shortcut to open bottom tab (Linter)
data.body:
<!--

Have you read Atom's Code of Conduct? By filing an Issue, you are expected to comply with it, including treating everyone with respect: https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md

Do you want to ask a question? Are you looking for support? The Atom message board is the best place for getting support: https://discuss.atom.io

-->

### Prerequisites

* [ X] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

I haven't found a means in which to open the bottom tab/drawer simply (i.e. like using `Ctrl + Shift + 9` to open the Git tab) in order to open, for instance, Linter (or any other package that may use such space)

**Expected behavior:** [What you expect to happen]

A simple keyboard shortcut to open the bottom tab.

**Reproduces how often:** [What percentage of the time does it reproduce?]

100%

### Versions

Atom    : 1.18.0
Electron: 1.3.15
Chrome  : 52.0.2743.82
Node    : 6.5.0

apm  1.18.1
npm  3.10.10
node 6.9.5 x64
python
git 2.13.2.windows.1
visual studio

Windows 10 Pro
Version 1703
OS Build 15063.483

### Additional Information

data.title: Atom had replaced my custom theme with Atom Dark
data.body: I'm using Atom for many monthes. And I've created my custom theme. Unfortunatly I've created it only on my local machine. I've choosen it some time ago and today I decided to try some other theme changing it in settings. When I've changed to another theme - it has changed, but when I wanted to change back to my custom theme, I found out that my custom theme was replaced with Atom Dark. I've checked files in c/users/username/github folder and they realy were replaced with Atom Dark. I have not expected this behaviour at all. Is there a way to restore files?

data.title: Gutter decoration regression in v1.19.0
data.body:
### Prerequisites
_Note: As only custom gutter decorations are affected, this is unable (?) to be tested in safe mode._

* [ ] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

The positioning of gutter decorations has regressed between Atom v1.18.0 and Atom v1.19.0-betaX (confirmed on -beta3). It seems that they are being shoved to the right ~50 pixels... and as their Z-index is below the editor's this effectively makes them invisible.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Have a package installed that creates a custom gutter. (ex. `linter-ui-default`)
2. Get that package to decorate a line.
3. Note that the gutter decorations aren't showing visibly.

#### Expected behavior:

Custom gutter icons show as they did in Atom v1.18.0.

Linter UI gutter on right in Atom v1.18.0:
![atom_2017-07-19_15-42-31](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/427137/28393440-9f830d02-6c9b-11e7-9606-2022bde8283c.png)

Linter UI gutter on left in Atom v1.18.0:
![atom_2017-07-19_15-42-58](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/427137/28393446-aefaf542-6c9b-11e7-951d-2cb46219944a.png)

#### Actual behavior:

Custom gutter icons are shifted to the right by a constant value (~50 px?), and background highlights don't show.

Linter UI gutter on right in Atom v1.19.0-beta3:
![atom_2017-07-19_15-49-17](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/427137/28393471-c4c60448-6c9b-11e7-914d-6df2990ec239.png)

Linter UI gutter on left in Atom v1.19.0-beta3:
![atom_2017-07-19_15-48-58](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/427137/28393474-c80f7b98-6c9b-11e7-8bde-4e27f5491ad0.png)

#### Reproduces how often:

100% of the time.

### Versions

```
OS: Windows 10 Enterprise x64
Atom    : 1.19.0-beta4
Electron: 1.6.9
Chrome  : 56.0.2924.87
Node    : 7.4.0
apm  1.18.2
npm  3.10.10
node 6.9.5 x64
python 2.7.13
git 2.13.3.windows.1
visual studio 2015
```

### Additional Information

The gutter decorations were first reported by @ooJerryLeeoo in https://github.com/steelbrain/linter-ui-default/issues/359, with the background highlighting pointed out by @50Wliu in https://github.com/steelbrain/linter-ui-default/pull/190#issuecomment-316501642 and elaborated on in https://github.com/steelbrain/linter-ui-default/issues/385.

data.title: Trouble building Atom on Windows 10
data.body:
### Prerequisites

* [x] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom

### Description

Tried for a while now to build atom on W10. Looked at every other isue relating, but with no luck.

Here is my error log; [raw_file](https://github.com/KvalheimRacing/atom-transparency/blob/master/npm-debug.log)

tried script/clean, and script/bootstrap, also, aswell as  ./script/build --create-windows-installer. No luck. I have another version of atom some place else, but that should not be a problem right? Tried, npm2, npm3 and now on npm5.

data.title: Atom modifies random lines in files tracked by source control when saving.
data.body:
<!--

Have you read Atom's Code of Conduct? By filing an Issue, you are expected to comply with it, including treating everyone with respect: https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md

Do you want to ask a question? Are you looking for support? The Atom message board is the best place for getting support: https://discuss.atom.io

-->

### Prerequisites

* [ X] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

Atom modifies random lines throughout the file on save or CMD + s

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Modify a line in a file which is being tracked in source control
2. Save the file
3. An unexpected line will appear as modified 

**Expected behavior:** Only lines that have been manually modified should show a yellow indicator as being modified

**Actual behavior:** A line which was not modified by me shows as changed in source control after saving the file.

**Reproduces how often:** [Has happened to me on both my work and home laptops]

### Versions

1.18.0

### Additional Information

![screen shot 2017-07-19 at 11 58 57 am](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/5935411/28384467-b6899a42-6c79-11e7-8e12-ecc828d0f0a8.png)
Actual line modified

![screen shot 2017-07-19 at 11 59 49 am](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/5935411/28384492-cd15d406-6c79-11e7-9c1b-f50a197363b9.png)
Random line which shows as modified after CMD+S

![screen shot 2017-07-19 at 12 42 54 pm](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/5935411/28386252-dc6bc216-6c7f-11e7-915c-68ee5cd0cc77.png)
And the resulting diff in version control

data.title: Sign manually without using Squirrel
Nomodulenamed tensorflow problem.
data.body:
I'm using windows OS and anaconda with atom.
I downloaded tensorflow at the anaconda virtual environment.
I can use it anaconda prompt, however, at the atom, I get Nomodulenamed tensorflow error message, when I'm writing import tensorflow as tf.
How can I solve this problem?
How can I use virtual environment at the atom in windows 10 OS?
Any reply will helpful to me.
Thanks.

data.title: OAuth Sign-In Screen for GitHub package says "not owned or operated by GitHub" when it is.
data.body:
<!--

Have you read Atom's Code of Conduct? By filing an Issue, you are expected to comply with it, including treating everyone with respect: https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md

Do you want to ask a question? Are you looking for support? The Atom message board is the best place for getting support: https://discuss.atom.io

-->

### Prerequisites

* [x] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode _(NA)_
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/ _(NA)_
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages _(NA)_

### Description

When the GitHub package for Atom is authorised using the browser on the OAuth page, the text at the bottom says 

> Not owned or operated by GitHub

![chrome_2017-07-19_15-53-14](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/24581770/28373516-71695fee-6c9a-11e7-854d-7d350032485c.png)

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Press Ctrl+Shift+8 to open the GitHub package panel in Atom. (I believe this requires GitHub for Desktop to be installed, but I'm not sure)
2. Click "Login" then follow the link
3. Authorise the Atom application, using password if necessary

**Expected behavior:** The OAuth page at the bottom shows "Owned and operated by GitHub". 

**Actual behavior:** The OAuth page at the bottom shows "Not owned or operated by GitHub". (see screenshot)

![chrome_2017-07-19_15-53-14](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/24581770/28373516-71695fee-6c9a-11e7-854d-7d350032485c.png)

**Reproduces how often:** Always (100% of the time)

### Versions

`Atom    : 1.18.0`

`Electron: 1.3.15`

`Chrome  : 52.0.2743.82`

`Node    : 6.5.0`

### Additional Information

I have GitHub for Desktop installed, version 0.7.0. Browser used was Chrome 59.

data.title: Uncaught Error: Requested measurement of a line that is not currently rendered

1. Open Atom-Beta
2. Create a new empty file
3. Paste some text into untitled file
